Role and responsibilities within the Breast Unit across MSE Trust ............................... 8
Introduction

The state of the art breast units provide a variety of services to the local population. The breast service unit has a well-established team of specialists who work within recognised guidelines for the management of all breast disorders.

The services provided include breast symptomatic (referrals from GP), breast screening (women 50-73 for mammograms 3 yearly), screening assessment clinics, surgical results clinics, surgical follow up clinics, breast oncology clinics, breast prosthesis fitting, arm lymphoedema clinic, family history screening, genetics clinic, oncology plastic service and breast care nurse support clinics.
Scope
The Breast Unit will treat all symptomatic patients from MEHT and a joint breast screening service from MEHT & ESNEFT.
Key Services Provided
One stop specialist / multidisciplinary specialist breast clinics where women are seen and assessed for their breast problem (see appendix 1).

Breast pain clinics where women are seen by a Breast Care Nurse and where advice and support is given, and a clinical examination & a mammogram is arranged if they are over 50 and not had one in the last 12 months.(see appendix 3)
NHS Breast Screening Service (NHSBSP) - This is for women aged  – 70, they are invited to attend for a mammogram every three years (see appendix 2).

Breast Screening Assessment Clinic - In this clinic women who have been screened through the NHSBSP are recalled if there is an abnormality on their mammogram. They will be re assessed by a Consultant Radiologist, the patient may have had the mammograms repeated. The mammograms will be read by the Consultant Radiologist, then the patient will be seen by the Consultant Radiologist, results of the mammogram explained, a clinical examination will be carried out, an Ultrasound scan and biopsy will be performed if necessary. All results will be explained to the patient in the presence of the breast screening nurse. The nurse will then discuss this further with the patient in a separate room (see appendix 2).
Breast imaging, ultrasound and mammography - these are carried out as part of a clinic (see appendix 4).

Prosthesis and lymphoedema clinics - These are nurse led clinics where patients who have had cancer are seen to have an external breast prosthesis fitted or to have their arm lymphoedema assessed and managed (see appendix 3).

Family history clinics - This is a nurse led clinic for women with a family history of breast cancer who are moderate to high risk patients. The nurse takes a full assessment using of the family history and explains to the individuals the risk to them and also discusses breast awareness and healthy lifestyle with

them.. They will also arrange for them to be entered into the family history screening programme. This will involve the patient attending the breast unit for a mammogram every two years until the age of fifty. Patients are referred for genetic screening if they meet the GOSH referral criteria.
Genetics clinics - This clinic is held every two weeks by a Genetic Counsellor – This service is provided by Great Ormond Street Hospital but held at the Breast Unit for convenience for the patients.

Localisation of impalpable lesions prior to surgery - This technique is carried out prior to an operation being performed. It is required for all impalpable lesions. The woman arrives at the Breast Unit at 0800 on the day of her operation. She will be seen by a Breast Care Nurse prior to the procedure to ensure she understands what is going to happen. She will then be taken to either the ultrasound room or the x-ray room where a wire will be inserted in to her breast under image guidance or a mark will be placed on her skin. If she has a wire inserted she will have a further mammogram to ensure the wire is in the correct place. She will be taken to ward by a member of the breast team.
Vacuum excision of benign lesions - Lesions are excised using either a 10g or 7g vacuum biopsy device under image guidance. Performed by either a Consultant Radiologist or Advanced Practitioner.

Research clinics - There is a team of research nurses who enters patients into clinical trials, they will provide the information about the trial to the patient and enrol them if they wish to participate. They will monitor the patient throughout the length of the trial. They will either have their own nurse led clinics or see the patients following a Consultant consultation.

Open Access Follow Up (OAFU) clinics - This is a specially designed programme for patients who have completed their treatment. It replaces the follow up clinics, it puts the patient back in control of their care, they will have a consultation with the OAFU nurse 3-4 months after completion of their treatment, surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

The hour long appointment will discuss their treatment summary (which is prepared in advance) and will include, diagnosis & histology, treatments they have had and possible side effects, endocrine therapy, signs & symptoms to report, being body aware, mammograms and bone density scans, healthy living, support after treatment has finished and signposting to other services and how to contact OAFU for support and advice.

The patient will be asked to complete an holistic needs assessment (HNA) prior to the appointment so it can be discussed at the appointment. The patient will receive a personised treatment summary and follow up plan, a copy of which is kept in the medical records and sent to the GP. (Appendix 10)

Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Breast Unit across MSE Trust

The breast unit service has a multidisciplinary team of surgeons, radiotherapists and nurses that meets weekly to discuss the results of investigations and surgery. They follow recognised national guidelines and local protocols to agree possible treatment choices. The results of the multidisciplinary team meetings are discussed with those patients concerned and a plan of action agreed jointly.
Oncologists and radiotherapists

After surgery some patients are referred to an oncologist, a doctor who specialises in cancer treatment. The oncologist will discuss with the patient whether additional treatment such as chemotherapy, hormone therapy or radiotherapy should be considered.
Pathologists

After breast surgery the tissue removed is sent to the pathologist who examines the specimen. Based upon their dissection and microscopic examination of the specimen, they are able to determine the tumour grade (how aggressive the cancer appears) and the stage (the size of the tumour and the extent to which it has already spread from the original site). The information that the pathologist provides assists the breast surgeon, oncologist and radiotherapist in choosing the best possible treatment for each patient.
Breast care nurses

Our breast care nurses work full time within the unit and provide holistic care and advice throughout the patient's 'cancer journey'. They are the first point of contact for patients should they have any problems during or after their treatment and are meet all patients at the time of diagnosis. Advice is given on treatments, alternatives and possible side effects.
Radiographers

Our breast unit is the base for both the symptomatic breast service and the breast screening service. Radiographers who work for these services have undergone a year's postgraduate training specialising in mammography (taking x-rays of the breast). They also train in the specialised areas of assessment mammography, assisting the radiologist in biopsy and pre-operative guide wire locations.
Support for patients

Specialist Breast Cancer Nurses work within the Breast Unit, and are present when patients are given their cancer diagnosis. They offer patients information, practical help, emotional support and continuity of care.

There are over 30 radiographers working within our breast unit and in Colchester Breast Unit, some of whom are extending their roles to become advanced practitioners. These radiographers will specialise in reading x-rays and performing breast ultrasound and carrying out breast biopsies.

The overall appearance and ambience of the breast unit must be non-clinical, calm and friendly.
Child friendly (accompanying mothers). Must be compliant with children's NSF.
Women attending for screening are essentially ‘well' and should be appropriately separated.
Patients should only get undressed once during the process.
Patient's notes and mammograms at Breast Unit for clinics, need to have good working relationship with medical records staff.
Data security and records management, all staff needs to be aware of this.

Security requirements
Data security
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT Policies.
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trust data sharing policy.
Hospital information / patient data will only be downloaded onto devices provided by the Trust which are encrypted.
Databases will be registered on the Trust database of databases.
A data mapping form will be completed for all routine data flows leaving the Trust.
Patient identifiable information will only be sent out of the Trust from an nhs.net account or other secure route (never from an nhs.uk account).
Out of hours the unit should be made secure.
All doors must be lockable.
Security for patients
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Patient Safety Policies
All staff must be screened through HR for CRB check.
All staff must wear name badges and carry Trust ID.
All patients are chaperoned according to the Trust Policy.
Security for staff
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Lone Worker and Security / Risk Management Policies.
Security for Patients and Staff – when necessary, Trust based security is available for patients and staff via the emergency phone / bleep numbers.
Medical records security
All patients medical records will be managed confidentially at all times and stored securely in locked office or outpatient facility whilst not in use.
All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's Case note Tracking Policy.
All new documentation will be secured into the folder prior to it leaving the department.
Manual handling
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Manual Handing Policies.
Fire safety
The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.”
(The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)

Work flows
Onestop Breast Clinic (see Appendix 1)
Patients are referred to the clinic from their GP, some will have appointments booked via the choose and book system.
The patient will be telephoned / sent an appointment to attend clinic.
On arrival the patient will book into reception and be asked to take a seat in the waiting room.
The volunteer / admin assistant takes the medical notes and will direct the patient to sit in the second waiting room.
The radiographer will take the patient notes and if appropriate will perform a mammogram.
Once the mammogram is performed the notes are taken to the ultrasound room, if no mammogram is required the notes are taken to the ultrasound room.
The patient is called in by the radiographer / nurse to see the Consultant Radiologist and Surgeon.
The patient's medical history is recorded and this is followed by a clinical examination, ultrasound scan and needle / core biopsy if required.

If a biopsy is carried out and a cancer is suspected, the Breast Care Nurse (BCN) will be asked to come to the clinic room. Once the patient is dressed, the BCN will take the patient to another room. along with their relative. Relatives are allowed to attend due to breaking bad news. he Consultant will explain the diagnosis to the patient and relative. The BCN will then support them and arrange the results clinic appointment and the patient will leave the department.
If a biopsy is carried out and no cancer is suspected, the patient will get dressed, leave the clinic room and book a results clinic appointment.
If no biopsy carried out the patient can leave the room and get dressed and leave the department.
Breast Screening (See Appendix 2)
Patients are invited by letter to attend their appointment for breast screening.
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
A mammographer will come and introduce themselves to the patient and take the patient to a mammogram room where a mammogram will be performed.
Following the mammogram procedure, the mammographer will talk with the patient and inform that they can now leave.
The patient will then be allowed to get dressed and leave the department.
Breast Screening Assessment Clinic (See Appendix 2)
All women will have had their case discussed at the breast screening MDT the morning of their assessment visit.
The letter recalling the patient to the assessment clinic will be assessed.
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The radiographer will perform additional mammograms if required.
The results of the mammograms will be taken to the radiologist in the ultrasound room.
The patient will then be called in by the nurse/radiographer to see the radiologist.
A clinical examination, ultrasound and biopsy might be performed if necessary.
The radiologist will then explain the results to the patient.
The screening nurse will then escort the patient to a clinic room to discuss the outcome of the appointment and book a biopsy results appointment if
necessary.
Leaves the department
Nurse Led Clinics (See Appendix 3)
The patient is referred by their GP, the breast care clinic or by themselves.
The appointment is then booked.
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The patient will be seen by a nurse, a breast prosthesis is fitted or a lymphoedema assessed and a garment fitted.
The patient will book a follow up appointment at reception if necessary.
The patient can then leave the department.
Localisation (See Appendix 4)
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The patient will then be seen by a breast care nurse (BCN) discussion re procedure, documentation completed.
The patient is then asked to wait in the waiting room.
Patient is then taken by radiographer to the ultrasound room or mammogram
room.
A localisation is performed and a secure dressing placed over the wire.
A mammogram test us repeated.
The patient is then asked to dress and asked to wait in waiting room to be escorted to the ward by a member of the breast care team.
Follow Up Clinic (See Appendix 5)
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The patient will be called by a nurse to see the consultant.
Reception to book a follow up appointment with the patient if required.
The patient can then leave the breast unit.
Results Clinic (See Appendix 6)
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The patient will be called by a nurse to see the consultant; the test results are then given.
Benign results
Reception to book a follow up appointment with patient if required.
The patient can then leave the breast unit.
Cancer result
Treatment planned; surgery, chemotherapy or hormone therapy.
Patient leaves with breast care nurse to another room to discuss treatment plan, written and verbal information given.
The breast care nurse books follow up appointment with the patient if required.
The patient can then leave the breast unit.
Seroma Clinic (See Appendix 7)
All patients will, on arrival at the unit, be asked to report to the breast unit reception.
Patients will be shown by a volunteer or admin staff where to take a seat in the waiting room.
The patient is called in to see breast care nurse.
Patient is asked to undress in the clinic room, the seroma is drained, and the patient asked to redress.
The patient can then leave the breast unit.
Emergency Flows
Patients with Breast Abscess (See Appendix 8)
Referred by GP to A&E or by GP direct to breast unit/consultant.
Patient is seen in breast unit at the next one stop clinic or the same day if the consultant is available.
Clinical examination and ultrasound scan performed.
The abscess is then drained.
Follow up appointment for the patient is booked in reception.
Patient leaves the department with a breast care nurse contact number.
Elective Flows (See Appendix 15)
The patient is given a date for their operation.
Patient is given information to ring and book a pre-assessment appointment.
An operation is booked with the waiting list department, letter sent to patient.
Patient is admitted to hospital for surgery either as in-patient or day stay patient.
The patient is seen on ward by breast care nurse, and a follow up appointment given.
Surgery is then performed.
The patient is then discharged from hospital.

data.text: Extended Breast Membership
Screening Staff

A team of radiographers are provided by ESNEFT (East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust) to provide this service. The National Health Service Breast Screening Programme is a combined service with Chelmsford and Colchester providing one service. ESNEFT is the host trust.
The MDT function

The MDT is a team of specialised clinicians working collaboratively to ensure a co- ordinated approach to treatment and care pathways for all patients diagnosed with breast cancer or pre-malignant disease. Any complex benign cases are discussed as well as management of recurrence and metastatic disease where appropriate.

The MDT should discuss a minimum of 100 new breast cases per year with individual breast surgeons should treat a minimum of 30 new cases per year and all core consultants (surgeons oncologists, histopathologists and radiologists) should spend at least 50% of direct clinical care sessions on breast work. All five breast care nurses spend at least 80% of their time on breast cancer.

The breast team meets weekly with either named leads or individuals that have been identified to cover. The MDT is a local discussion at the Breast Centre. The meetings are chaired by the Lead clinician or cover in his absence.

All patients with suspected breast cancer are discussed at the MDT following the clinic appointment, after surgery and after any investigations. All patients who have core biopsies, any C3 cytology results and any discrepant triple assessment patients are also discussed.
Any patient who needs treatment prior to the next MDT will be discussed individually by the surgeon with the radiologist, oncologist and histopathologist
The attendance at all meetings is recorded and is attached at appendix
The core MDT members agree and record individual patient treatment plans in accordance with IOG guidelines.
A record of all patients discussed is kept in addition to the treatment plans.
The current system is the Somerset system.
We very rarely have referrals which need treatment planning prior to the next MDT but if we do have a referral we would discuss it with the team on an individual basis.
Workload - between 400 & 450 new breast cancers every year. Please see details in annual report.
Co-ordination of care / patient pathways

The service follows the network agreed guidelines for referrals, imaging, pathology and follow up, although there may be some variations at each unit. This is all documented in the network guidelines.
NSSG have agreed clinical and referral guidelines which the team adhere to. The NSSG also have agreed diagnosis assessment imaging and pathology guidelines which the team adhere to.
Patient communication
All patients diagnosed with breast cancer will be given a key worker, this is either the Lead Nurse for Breast Care or a Breast Care Sister.
All patients that attend breast cancer clinics and nurse led clinics are offered a summary of the clinic consultation.

All patients and their carer's are provided with clear and comprehensive verbal and written information. (Patient folder) They will have the opportunity to discuss their condition with key members of the MDT.
Following surgery, at the time of discharge, the date for the first outpatient follow up appointment will be given to the patient prior to leaving the hospital.
If they have been treated as a day case, the Breast Care Nurse will contact them the next day to inform them of their outpatient appointment.
The Breast Care Nurse Specialists are the co-ordinators for patient information and, therefore, responsible for quality assurance of all the information given to the patients.

It is the responsibility of the Breast Care Nurse Specialist to ensure that user issues are addressed and that written information is produced in partnership with user groups. Standards will be maintained through annual audit / patient survey. Patient information will be regularly reviewed and updated.

All patients with breast cancer will have access to a user support group based at the Broomfield Hospital. This group meets once a month, third Wednesday, and is run by patients for patients with the support of the Breast Care Nurse Specialists. The group offers support and information. Patients with wish to participate can contact the Breast Care Nurses or. Information will also be provided in the patient information folders.
Written information for patients
Patients will receive information folders and will include information on cancer in general and on breast cancer. Specifically:
Surgical procedures.
Treatment options.
Risk of lymphoedema.
Pre and post-operative care.
List of MDT members.
They will also receive appropriate booklets produced by Breast Cancer Now.
Written and verbal information regarding fertility will be given to younger women.

It is recognised that all patients should have access to verbal and written information about cancer and their condition. Not all patients speak English or are able to hear, see or read. In Mid Anglia this is faced less often than other networks where cultural diversity is more widespread. However all patients and carers will have access to translation services for verbal & written information (refer to the Trust's Interpreting & Translation Policy. If more specialist information is required, this will be produced on a patient-to-patient basis.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Breast Unit Consultants and Doctors Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local breast unit guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Breast Unit Consultants and Doctors Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
